revision.text:
{{:Radiation Oncology/Hodgkin/TOC}}
<big>'''Hodgkin's Lymphoma: Early Stage Favorable'''</big>
==Guidelines== *'''American College of Radiology; 2008''' PMID 18812149 -- "ACR Appropriateness Criteria on Hodgkin's lymphoma: favorable prognosis stage I and II." (Das P, J Am Coll Radiol. 2008 Oct;5(10):1054-66.) **[http://www.acr.org/SecondaryMainMenuCategories/quality_safety/app_criteria/pdf/ExpertPanelonRadiationOncologyhodgkinsWorkGroup/FavorablePrognosisStageIandIIhodgkinsdiseaseUpdateinProgressDoc1.aspx Guideline link]
==Favorable prognostic factors== *<u>NCCN guidelines</u>: no bulky disease, 1-3 involved regions, 1 extranodal site, no B symptoms, ESR <50 *<u>ACR appropriateness criteria</u>: no bulky mediastinal disease, 1-3 involved regions, no B symptoms *<u>EORTC</u>: age <=50, no bulky mediastinal adenopathy, 1-3 involved regions, no B symptoms and ESR <50, B symptoms and ESR <30
==RT Alone: Field Size== *If patients negative subdiaphragmatic disease by staging laparotomy, Mantle field alone sufficient compared with STNI *If patients clinically negative, Mantle field alone insufficient, however, STNI sufficient without requiring surgical staging
*'''EORTC H7-Very Favorable''' -- no staging laparoscopy + Mantle RT **'''1997''' <u>ASTRO Abstract</u> -- "Combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy is advisable in all patients with clinical stage I-II Hodgkin's disease. Six-year results of the EORTC-GPMC controlled clinical trials 'H7-VF', 'H7-F' and 'H7-U'." (Noordijk EM, Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 1997; 39(2):S173 ***Very favorable group subset (female, age <40, stage IA, NS/LP histology, ESR <50) treated with Mantle only, without PA field ***Outcome: 6-year RFS 73%, OS 96% ***Conclusion: Relapse rate unacceptably high in these clinically staged patients with Mantle RT only; arm closed
*'''EORTC H6-Favorable''' (1982-1988) -- staging laparoscopy + Mantle RT vs clinical staging + STNI **Randomized. 262 patients, favorable prognosis (1-2 nodal areas, no bulky disease, no B symptoms and ESR <50, B symptoms and ESR <30). Arm 1) No staging laparotomy, Mantle + PA RT 40 Gy vs Arm 2) Staging laparotomy (-), Mantle RT 40 Gy **'''1993''' PMID 7693881 -- ""Clinical staging versus laparotomy and combined modality with MOPP versus ABVD in early-stage Hodgkin's disease: the H6 twin randomized trials from the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Lymphoma Cooperative Group." (Carde P, J Clin Oncol. 1993 Nov;11(11):2258-72.) Median F/U 5.3 years ***Outcome: In patients undergoing lap, 33% found lap (+). 6-year FFP laparoscopy + Mantle 83% vs Mantle + PA 78% (NS); 6-year OS 89% vs 93% (NS) ***Conclusion: No difference between surgical staging + mantle vs clinical staging + STNI
*'''EORTC H5-Favorable''' (1977-82) -- Mantle 40 Gy vs STNI 40 Gy **Randomized. 198 patients, favorable (age <=40, ESR <=70, LP/NS, Stage I or Stage II without mediastinal involvement), negative staging laparotomy. Arm 1) Mantle RT 40 Gy vs Arm 2) Mantle RT + PA RT (T11-L4) 40 Gy **'''1988''' PMID 2578012 -- "Clinical stages I and II Hodgkin's disease: a specifically tailored therapy according to prognostic factors." (Carde P, J Clin Oncol. 1988 Feb;6(2):239-52.) Median F/U 5.3 years ***Outcome: 6-year RFS mantle 74% vs mantle+PA 72% (NS); 6-year OS 96% vs 89% (NS) ***Conclusion: In surgically staged patients, more limited RT (mantle alone) is sufficient
==RT Alone: Dose== *'''German HD4''' (1988-1994) -- All IFRT 40 Gy, EFRT 40 Gy vs EFRT 30 Gy **Randomized. 376 patients, Stage I-II, no risk factors (large mediastinal mass, extranodal lesions, massive splenic disease, elevated ESR, 3+ involved areas). Involved field RT 40 Gy. Arm 1) EFRT 40 Gy vs Arm 2) EFRT 30 Gy. No chemotherapy **'''2001''' PMID 11387364 -- "Low-dose radiation is sufficient for the noninvolved extended-field treatment in favorable early-stage Hodgkin's disease: long-term results of a randomized trial of radiotherapy alone." (Duhmke E, J Clin Oncol. 2001 Jun 1;19(11):2905-14.) Median F/U 7.2 years ***Outcome: 7-year RFP 40 Gy 78% vs 30 Gy 83% (NS); 7-year OS 91% vs 96% (NS). Worse outcome (RFS 72% vs 84%) with protocol violations ***Conclusion: 30 Gy dose adequate for clinically noninvolved areas
==RT vs Chemo-RT== *'''German HD7''' (1993-1998) -- ABVD x2 + EFRT vs EFRT alone **Randomized. 650 patients, Stage IA-IIB without risk factors. Treated with 1) RT alone vs. 2) ABVD x 2 cycles + RT RT same in both arms, given as EFRT 30 Gy + IFRT 10 Gy **'''2007''' PMID 17606976 -- "Two cycles of doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine plus extended-field radiotherapy is superior to radiotherapy alone in early favorable Hodgkin's lymphoma: final results of the GHSG HD7 trial." (Engert A, J Clin Oncol. 2007 Aug 10;25(23):3495-502.). Median F/U 7.2 years ***7-year outcome: no difference in survival (92% vs. 94%, NS), but significant difference in DFS RT alone 67% vs. CRT 88% (SS). Treatment relapse more successful for RT only arm ***Second malignancies: no difference, 0.8% per year, highest in older patients & B-symptoms ***Conclusion: Combined modality more effective than EF-RT alone
*'''EORTC H8-Favorable''' (1993-1999) -- MOPP-ABV x3 + IFRT vs STNI alone **Randomized. 542 patients, Stage I-II supradiaphragmatic HD, favorable (Prognostic score using [[Radiation_Oncology/Hodgkin/EORTC|EORTC H7]] criteria 1-5). Arm 1) [[Radiation_Oncology/Chemotherapy_combinations#MOPP-ABV|MOPP-ABV]] x3 cycles + IFRT (36 Gy if CR, 40-44 Gy if PR) vs. Arm 2) STNI alone (36 Gy + 4 Gy boost to involved fields) **'''2007''' PMID 17989384 -- "Chemotherapy plus involved-field radiation in early-stage Hodgkin's disease." (Ferme C, N Engl J Med. 2007 Nov 8;357(19):1916-27.). Median F/U 7.7 years ***H8-F Outcome: 5-year EFS MOPP-ABV + IFRT 98% vs. STNI 74% (SS); 10-year OS 97% vs. 92% (SS) ***Conclusion: For favorable disease, MOPP-ABV x3 cycles + IFRT is superior to STNI
*'''EORTC H7-Favorable''' (1988-1993) -- EBVP x6 + IFRT vs STNI alone **Randomized. 333 patients with Stage I supradiaphragmatic HL, favorable (prognostic score 1-5). No staging laparotomy. Arm 1) STNI alone (36 Gy + 4Gy boost to involved fields) vs. Arm 2) [[Radiation_Oncology/Chemotherapy_combinations#EBVP|EBVP]] x6 cycles + IFRT (36-40 Gy) **'''2006''' PMID 16754934 — "Combined-modality therapy for clinical stage I or II Hodgkin's lymphoma: long-term results of the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer H7 randomized controlled trials." (Noordijk EM, J Clin Oncol. 2006 Jul 1;24(19):3128-35.) Median F/U 8.7 years ***Outcome: 10-yr EFS STNI 78% vs. EBVP+IF 88% (SS). OS similar at 92%. ***Conclusion: Combined EBVP x6 + IFRT is superior STNI alone
==Chemo-RT: RT Dose== *'''EORTC H9-Favorable''' (1998-2004) -- EBVP x6 followed IFRT 36 Gy vs IFRT 20 Gy vs No RT **Randomized. ''Arm 3 stopped early due to >20% of failure.'' 783 favorable Stage I-II patients enrolled, 619 achieved CR(u) on EBVP x6 and were randomized. Arm 1) 36 Gy IF-RT Arm vs. 2) 20 Gy IF-RT vs. 3) no RT. Arm 3 stopped early due to high recurrence (>20%). **'''2005''' [http://www.asco.org/ASCOv2/Meetings/Abstracts?&vmview=abst_detail_view&confID=34&abstractID=30245 ASCO abstract] -- "First results of the EORTC-GELA H9 randomized trials: the H9-F trial (comparing 3 radiation dose levels) and H9-U trial (comparing 3 chemotherapy schemes) in patients with favorable or unfavorable early stage Hodgkin‚Äôs lymphoma (HL)." (Noordijk, EM ASCO 2005). Median F/U 2.7 years ***Outcome: 4-year EFS 36 Gy 87% vs 20 Gy 84% vs. no RT 70% (SS). 4 yr OS 98% in all arms. ***Conclusion: In favorable patients in CR after 6 cycles of EBVP, omission of IFRT leads to unacceptable failure rate; 20 Gy provides comparable control as 36 Gy
*'''HD10''' (1998-2002) -- 2x2: ABVD x2 vs ABVD x4; IFRT 30 Gy vs 20 Gy **Randomized, 2x2. 1370 pts. Stage IA, IB, IIA, IIB (Note only ~7% of patients had B Symptoms) without risk factors (ie, large mediastinal mass, size >1/3 of the maximum thorax diameter, extranodal disease, 3 or more nodal areas, or elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (> 50 mm/h for stages IA, IIA and > 30 mm/h for stages IB, IIB). Randomization #1) ABVD x4 cycles vs ABVD x2 cycles, and randomization #2) IFRT 30 Gy vs IFRT 20 Gy **'''2009; 5-years''' ASH Abstract #716 [http://ash.confex.com/ash/2009/webprogram/Paper21388.html Abstract] - No PMID (Abstract only) — "Two Cycles of ABVD Followed by Involved Field Radiotherapy with 20 Gray (Gy) Is the New Standard of Care in the Treatment of Patients with Early-Stage Hodgkin Lymphoma: Final Analysis of the Randomized German Hodgkin Study Group (GHSG) HD10." (Engert A; Dec 2009) Median F/U 6.6 years ***ABVD Outcome: No significant difference in 5-year OS, FFTF, or PFS between ABVD x 4 and ABVD x 2 (OS 97% vs 97%; FFTF 93% vs 91%; PFS 93% vs 91%). ***IFRT Outcome: No significant difference between IFRT 30 Gy vs 20 Gy (OS 98% vs 97%, FFTF 93% vs 93%, PFS 94% vs 93%). No difference when all 4 arms compared. ***Conclusion: 2 cycles of ABVD followed by 20 Gy IFRT is the new standard for GHSG for early favorable HD **'''2010; 5-years''' PMID 20818855 -- "Reduced Treatment Intensity in Patients with Early-Stage Hodgkin's Lymphoma" (Engert A, N Engl J Med 2010 Aug 12;363(7):640-652.) ***For comparison of ABVD 2 cycles vs 4 cycles, no difference in FFTF or OS -- 5-yr FFTF 93.0% (ABVD x 4) vs 91.1% (ABVD x 2). For comparison of RT dose, no differences. Percent of grade 3/4 toxicities higher in group of ABVD x 4 vs ABVD x 2, 55% vs 33 % p=sig and XRT 30 Gy vs 20 Gy, 8.7% vs 2.9% p=sig. 6 treatment related deaths occured in ABVD x 4 vs 1 death in ABVD x 2. ***Conclusion: ABVD x 2 + 20 Gy IFRT is as effective as ABVD x 4 + 30 Gy.
==Chemo-RT vs Chemo Alone== *'''EORTC H10''' -- PET scan guided early treatment adaptation (omission of RT) **See details at: [[Radiation_Oncology/Hodgkin/EORTC#H10 | H10]] **Conclusion: "combined-modality treatment resulted in fewer early progressions in clinical stage I/II HL"
*'''EORTC H9-Favorable''' (1998-2004) -- EBVP x6 followed IFRT 36 Gy vs IFRT 20 Gy vs No RT **Randomized. ''Arm 3 stopped early due to >20% of failure.'' 783 favorable Stage I-II patients enrolled, 619 achieved CR(u) on EBVP x6 and were randomized. Arm 1) 36 Gy IF-RT Arm vs. 2) 20 Gy IF-RT vs. 3) no RT. Arm 3 stopped early due to high recurrence (>20%). **'''2005''' [http://www.asco.org/ASCOv2/Meetings/Abstracts?&vmview=abst_detail_view&confID=34&abstractID=30245 ASCO abstract] -- "First results of the EORTC-GELA H9 randomized trials: the H9-F trial (comparing 3 radiation dose levels) and H9-U trial (comparing 3 chemotherapy schemes) in patients with favorable or unfavorable early stage Hodgkin‚Äôs lymphoma (HL)." (Noordijk, EM ASCO 2005). Median F/U 2.7 years ***Outcome: 4-year EFS 36 Gy 87% vs 20 Gy 84% vs. no RT 70% (SS). 4 yr OS 98% in all arms. ***Conclusion: In favorable patients in CR after 6 cycles of EBVP, omission of IFRT leads to unacceptable failure rate; 20 Gy provides comparable control as 36 Gy

page.title: User:RekonDog/Definitive History of the United States Marine Corps/Operations

revision.text:
:See also: ''[[User:RekonDog/Sandbox/Definitive History of the United States Marine Corps/Appendix|Definitive History of the United States Marine Corps‚Äî Appendix]]''
==American War for Independence [1775‚Äì1783]== ===Hopkins's Expedition, 1776=== Commodore [[w:Esek Hopkins|Esek Hopkins]] fleet‚Äîalong with marine detachments of 230 men‚Äîdeparted Philadelphia on 4 January 1776. Samuel Nicholas's Continental marines embarked onto five vessels for their maiden voyage: [[w:USS Alfred (1774)|USS ''Alfred'']]‚ÄîHopkins [[w:flagship|flagship]], [[w:USS Andrew Doria (1775)|USS ''Andrew Doria'']], [[w:USS Cabot (1775)|USS ''Cabot'']], [[w:USS Columbus (1774)|USS ''Columbus'']], and [[w:USS Providence (1775)|USS ''Providence'']]; comprising the entirety of the Continental Navy.<ref name=Hoffman/> One of Hopkins's captains in command of USS ''Columbus'', the recently commissioned Captain [[w:Abraham Whipple|Abraham Whipple]] (and resigned Commodore of the [[w:Rhode Island Navy|Rhode Island Navy]]), performed this exact task in clearing the [[w:The Carolinas|Carolina]] coast of enemy shipping many months earlier, before his commission into the Continental navy. This was the first [[w:expeditionary warfare|amphibious/expedition]] for the Continental Navy-Marine Corps. Hopkins was given the task to patrol the southern American coastline to intercept and clear any presence of British troops along the [[w:Delaware River|Delaware River]], and [[w:Chesapeake Bay|Chesapeake Bay]], then return north to New England and perform similar services.<ref>Letter: Naval Committee to Commodore Esek Hopkins (5 January 1776); NDAR, III: 637‚Äì638.</ref>
The next day [5 January], they sailed down the Delaware River and its approaches off [[w:Liberty Island|Liberty Island (Mud Island)]]. After dusk, the weather turned bitterly cold, freezing the river shore to shore. They remained stuck for more than a week. Momentarily, during the first thaw, [[w:USS Providence (1775)|USS ''Providence'']] joined the Continental fleet. On 17 January, the ships dropped further downstream to [[w:Port Penn|Port Penn]] on the Delaware shore behind [[w:Reedy Island|Reedy Island]] where cold weather returned and they were again ice-bound. They remained there until 11 February when Hopkins was able to move them to [[w:Cape Henlopen|Cape Henlopen]]. On 13 February, the small [[w:sloop|sloop]]s [[w:USS Fly (1776)|USS ''Fly'']], [[w:USS Hornet (1775)|USS ''Hornet'']], and the [[w:schooner|schooner]] [[w:USS Wasp (1775)|USS ''Wasp'']], traveling from [[w:Colony of Maryland|Maryland]], joined Hopkins's squadron off the [[w:Delaware Capes|capes of Delaware]]. However, two nights out, off the [[w:Virginia Capes|Virginia capes]] USS ''Fly'' fouled USS ''Hornet'' and both was forced to return to home port for repairs.
By 17 February, warmer temps thawed the ice and Hopkins's fleet sailed back out to sea. During this delayed period allowed Hopkins to monitor the British forces at Reedy Island for some six weeks. For reasons that remain obscure, he disobeyed his ambitious orders to safeguard the southern American coastline as he considered his orders discretionary and the enemy too strong; without proper authority he directed his squadron to head south en route to the [[w:West Indies|West Indies]] bypassing the Chesapeake Bay. <ref name="Hopkins (Britannica)">[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/271525/Esek-Hopkins A Biography of Commodore E. Hopkins (Britannica)]</ref> Hopkins's orders made strategic sense.<ref name=Millet/> Since rebel warships were already active off the New England coast, and the [[w:Middle Colonies|Middle Colonies]] were forming their own [[w:coast guard|coastal defense navies]], he ultimately knew that the American colonies desperately needed gunpowder. He decided to attack the island of [[w:New Providence|New Providence]] in the [[w:Bahamas|Bahamas]] to capture a large supply of that commodity as well as a great quantity of other military supplies reportedly stored there. On the morning of 3 March, Hopkins captured [[w:Fort Montague|Fort Montague]] in the bloodless [[w:battle of Nassau|battle of Nassau]], in which Continental marines under Capt. Samuel Nicholas conducted their ''first'' [[w:amphibious warfare|amphibious operation]].
====Battle of Nassau==== [[File:Battle of Nassau.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Painting of Continental Marines landing on a tropical beach from rowboats, with two ships in the background|Continental Marines land at [[w:New Providence|New Providence]] during the [[w:Battle of Nassau|Battle of Nassau]]]] Arriving in the [[w:Caribbean|Caribbean]], Commodore Esek Hopkins's main Continental fleet‚Äîand Captain Samuel Nicholas's Continental marines‚Äîreached [[w:Abaco Islands|Abaco]] in the [[w:Bahamas|Bahamas]], on the evening of 1 March 1776; the next day, Hopkins began laying plans for the raid on [[w:New Providence|New Providence]]. On 3 March 1776, the Continental Marines made their ''first'' epitomized amphibious landing in American history when they attempted an amphibious assault during the [[w:Battle of Nassau|Battle of Nassau]]. USS ''Wasp'' and USS ''Providence'' covered the marines as they went ashore to assault the British [[w:Fort Montagu|Fort Montagu]] hoping to seize supplies and provisions‚Äîof 234 of marines, and some fifty seamen‚Äîbut their guns never fired because the landing force found the beaches unopposed. Because the landing went forward several miles to the east of the town, it caused them to fail in achieving a surprise attack.<ref name="RevMarines"> {{cite book |last=Smith |first=Charles Richard |coauthors=[[w:Charles Waterhouse (artist)|Charles H. Waterhouse]] |title=A Pictoral History: the Marines in the Revolution |publisher=United States Marine Corps Historical Division |year=1975 |url=http://www.marines.mil/news/publications/Documents/A%20Pictorial%20History-The%20Marines%20in%20the%20Revolution%20PCN%2019000317900.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-08-22}} </ref> That evening, Hopkins issued a proclamation which promised not to harm: :''"...the persons or property of the inhabitants of New Providence..."'' if they did not resist.<ref> {{cite book |title=Essays in the Economic History of the Atlantic world |first=John J. |last=McCusker |ref=McCusker |publisher=Routledge |year=1997 |isbn=9780415168410}} </ref>
The following morning [4 March], they marched to [[w:Fort Nassau|Fort Nassau]] to seize more shots, shells, and cannons. However, the failure of surprise the day before had warned the defenders and allowed British Governor [[w:Montfort Browne|Montfort Browne]] to escape with a merchantman ship to [[w:St. Augustine, Florida|St. Augustine, Florida]], leaving all but 24 casks of powder out of the 174. And from other military stores captured, the marines and sailors took a large quantity of cannons‚Äîclose to 90 pieces, and 15 brass mortars. .<ref> {{cite book |title=Homeward Bound: A History of the Bahama Islands to 1850 with a Definitive of Abaco in the American Loyalist Plantation Period |first=Sandra |last=Riley |coauthors=Peters, Thelma B. |publisher=Riley Hall |year=2000 |ref=Riley}} </ref> However, the cache had more than justified the enterprise. Hopkins's fleet remained at Nassau for about two weeks loading the booty of war. So large was the take that several local ships had to be pressed into service to carry the materiel back to [[w:New England|New England]]. These acquired [[w:mat√©riel|mat√©riels]] were essential to the supply armament of the Continental Army. USS ''Fly'' was able to rejoin the squadron off New Providence 11 March‚Äîalthough USS ''Hornet'' remained behind‚Äîfinding that the operation had been a great success, and that a large quantity of military stores sorely needed had already been acquired and loaded. After the marines and sailors stripped the forts of their guns and all remaining ordnance, Commodore Hopkins finally hoisted sail on 17 March and withdrew from New Providence, hoisted sail and set course back north toward the Atlantic seas. USS ''Andrew Doria'' became the fleet's [[w:hospital ship|hospital ship]] after the other ships had an outbreak of smallpox. USS ''Andrew Doria'' was not affected as its crew had been inoculated.<ref name=Hoffman> {{cite book |last = Hoffman |first = Jon T. |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = USMC: A Complete History | publisher = Universe Publishing |year = 2002 |location = New York City, New York |url = |doi = |isbn = }} </ref> <ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.nassau.navy.mil/site%20pages/history.aspx |publisher=US Navy |accessdate=2010-01-03 |title=History of USS ''Nassau'' (LHA-4)}} </ref> USS ''Wasp'', however, parted with the main fleet and made her way independently back to the [[w:Delaware Capes|Delaware capes]] and thence into port at [[w:Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], where it arrived on 4 April.
====USS ''Alfred''‚ÄîHMS ''Glasglow''==== Returning from the Nassau expedition in the Bahamas, the flagship USS ''Alfred '' led the Commodore Hopkins's Continental fleet homeward from Nassau harbor on 17 March 1776; the same day British troops were evacuating Boston. Hoping to catch more easy prizes, on the evening of 4 April, Hopkins sailed inbound to [[w:Block Island|Block Island]] in [[w:Rhode Island|Rhode Island]]. He encountered the British six-gun schooner [[w:HMS Hawk (1775)|HMS ''Hawk'']], and the next day [5 April], the eight-gun bomb brigantine [[w:HMS Bolton (1775)|HMS ''Bolton'']] while off [[w:Montauk Point State Park|Montauk point]], [[w:Long Island|Long Island]]. The Continental sailors and marines boarded and seized both ships after a disgruntled close quarters fight, and claimed them as their [[w:prize (law)|prize]].
Shortly after midnight on 6 April, Hopkins encountered the [[w:frigate|frigate]] [[w:HMS Glasgow (1757)|HMS ''Glasgow'']], a 20-gun [[w:sixth-rate|sixth-rate]] warship under the command of navy captain [[w:Tryingham Howe|Tryingham Howe]]. While en route, HMS ''Glasgow'' was carrying dispatches of British troops that withdrawn from [[w:Newport, Rhode Island|Newport, Rhode Island]], and were sailing to meet the [[w:Kingdom of Great Britain|British]] fleet awaiting off the coast of [[w:Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston, South Carolina]]. This fleet had been assembled to launch an assault against the American forces in Charleston, which later it ultimately failed in the [[w:Battle of Sullivan's Island|Battle of Sullivan's Island]] on 28 June 1776. A fierce cannonade was exchanged between the American small flotilla and the British ship ''Glasgow'' and its destroyer tenders; despite the superiority in gunnery and seamanship, after and hour, HMS ''Glasgow'' managed to effectively escape from the heavy-laden American ships. Also, the Americans aimed their cannons too high, injuring only the sails and rigging. After dawn, HMS ''Glasgow'' disappeared over the horizon.<ref name="Hopkins (Britannica)"> [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/271525/Esek-Hopkins A Biography of Commodore E. Hopkins (Britannica)] </ref> Some of Hopkins ships in the fleet did attempt to chase however, the cannonade had cut the tiller ropes of USS ''Alfred'', leaving Hopkins' flagship unable to maneuver or to pursue the fleeing British ship. The USS ''Andrew Doria'' also sustained damage and was in need of repairs. Hopkins quickly became reluctant over his decision to chase HMS ''Glasgow'' due to the situation and continued to [[w:New London, Rhode Island|New London, Rhode Island]]. Four Marines wounded and seven killed; Lieutenant John Fitzpatrick was the first Continental marine killed in combat.<ref name=Hoffman/>
He formed his squadron into a scouting formation of two columns: the right (eastern) column was headed by the USS ''Cabot'', followed by Hopkins' flagship, the USS ''Alfred''; and the left (western) column was headed by the USS ''Andrew Doria'', followed by the USS ''Columbus''; behind these came the USS ''Providence'', with USS ''Fly'' and USS ''Wasp'', trailing further behind as escorts for the prizes. Hopkins's squadron reached [[w:New London, Connecticut|New London]] on 8 April 1776.
After refitting the damaged ships in his fleet, Commodore Hopkins then proceed to Block Island, reaching it by 16 April 1776, with six of his warships, and his four small prize ships.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.nassau.navy.mil/site%20pages/history.aspx |publisher=US Navy |accessdate=2010-01-03 |title=History of USS Nassau (LHA-4)}} </ref>
On the banks of [[w:Newfoundland|Newfoundland]], USS ''Andrew Doria'' captured two armed transports filled with soldiers, and made prizes of so many merchantmen that when he returned to the Delaware. Biddle retained but five of his original crew, the rest having been placed on board prizes.
===Interim: March‚ÄìDecember 1776=== As the Commander-in-Chief Esek Hopkins's Continental fleet sailed on its maiden voyage for [[w:New Providence|New Providence]], in the [[w:Bahamas|Bahamas]]; in February, the [[w:Marine Committee|Marine Committee]] fitted out other Continental vessels, two brigantines ‚Äîthe [[w:USS Lexington (1776)|USS ''Lexington'']] and [[w:USS Reprisal (1776)|USS ''Reprisal'']], of 16-guns each; and the sloops [[w:USS Independence (1776 sloop)|USS ''Independence'']] and [[w:USS Sachem (1776)|USS ''Sachem'']], of 10-guns each; and [[w:USS Mosquito (1775)|USS ''Mosquito'']] of 4-guns. These ships cruised along the littoral edge of the [[w:Middle Colonies|Middle Colonies]].
====USS ''Lexington''‚ÄîHMS ''Edward''==== On 26 March 1776, Captain [[w:John Barry (naval officer)|John Barry]] was issued orders from the [[w:Marine Committee|Marine Committee]] to sail his seamen and Continental marines aboard the USS ''Lexington'' and [[w:USS Wasp (1775)|USS ''Wasp'']] (commandeered by [[w:William Hallock (naval officer)|William Hallock]]) down the [[w:Delaware River|Delaware River]] to dispose the British frigate [[w:HMS Roebuck (1774)|HMS ''Roebuck'']] that was recently sighted offshore the [[w:Delaware Capes|capes of Delaware]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://etext.virginia.edu/etcbin/toccer-new2?id=DelVol25.xml&images=images/modeng&data=/texts/english/modeng/parsed&tag=public&part=510&division=div1 |title=Letter from Marine Committee to John Barry |author=Delegate to Congress |date=March 1788‚ÄìJuly 1789 |work=Letters of delegates to Congress, 1774-1789; Volume 25, , [with Supplement] |publisher=Electronic Text Center, University of Virginia Library |accessdate=3 April 2010}} </ref> They set sail on 31 March, and managed to slip through the British [[w:blockade|blockade]]. However, the next day [7 April], USS ''Lexington'' encountered the sloop [[w:USS Sachem (1776)|HMS ''Edward'']], off the [[w:Virginia Capes|capes of Virginia]].<ref name=Millet> {{cite book | last=Millet | first=Allan R. | title=Semper Fidelis: The History of the United States Marine Corps |publisher=[[w:Free Press (publisher)|The Free Press]] | year=1991 | location=[[w:New York City|New York City, New York]] | isbn=1-59114-790-5}} </ref>
HMS ''Edward'' is a [[w:destroyer tender|destroyer tender]] for the British [[w:man-of-war|man-of-war]] [[w:HMS Liverpool (1758)|HMS ''Liverpool'']]. After a desperate fight‚Äîof one hour and twenty minutes‚Äîbetween the American and British forces, the American sailor and marines eventually overwhelmed the British, HMS ''Edward'' finally [[w:Striking the colors|struck her colors]]. This event became the American navy's ''first'' victory over a British warship. USS ''Lexington'' sailed back for repairs. April 7, in sight of the [[w:Virginia Capes|Virginia capes]], Captain John Barry of the USS ''Lexington'' reported to the Marine Committee: :"I have the pleasure to acquaint you that at one P.M. this day I fell in with the sloop ''Edward'', belonging to the ''Liverpool'' frigate. She engaged us near two glasses. They killed two of our men and wounded two more. We shattered her in a terrible manner, as you will see. We killed and wounded several of her crew. I shall give you a particular account of the powder and arms taken out of her, as well as my proceedings in general. I have the happiness to acquaint you that all our people behaved with much courage."‚ÄîPennsylvania Gazette, April 17, 1776.<ref>Am. Arch., IV, v, 810, V, ii, 823; Almon, iii, 81; Griffin's Life of Barry, 30; Barney, 45, 46; N. E. Chronicle, April 25, 1776</ref>
Once the ship was refitted, Captain John Barry (USS ''Lexington'') sailed back out to sea on 26 April.
====USS ''Lexington''‚ÄîHMS ''Roebuck''==== While sailing the Delaware Capes, on 5 May 1776, Captains John Barry (USS ''Lexington'') and William Hallock (USS ''Wasp''), and its destroyer tenders, encountered [[w:Sir Peter Parker, 1st Baronet|Sir Peter Parker's]] fleet of two British men-of-war, the 44-gun HMS ''Roebuck'' and 28-gun HMS ''Liverpool'', escorted by a number of tenders and prizes, which were sailing to attack [[w:Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston, South Carolina]]. In the past, they had been raiding colonies, destroying tobacco farms, blockading merchants, in an effort to disrupt the commerce that helps finance the American Revolutionary War. The British fleet, having the advantage in fire superiority gave chase after eight hours of close-proximity cannonade. However, Captain Barry (USS ''Lexington'') finally managed to escape his pursuers and Captain Hallock (USS ''Wasp'') retreated into [[w:Christiana River|Christiana Creek]]. The HMS ''Roebuck'' was considerably injured in her rigging and, in attempting to get near the galleys, grounded on a shoal; the HMS ''Liverpool'' anchored near by for her protection. USS ''Reprisal'' and USS ''Hornet'' was in the bay nearby, although they took no part in the action, may have contributed to the discomfort of the Englishmen's situation.<ref>Am. Arch., IV, vi, 395, 408, 498, 809-811; Almon, iii, 173; Boston Gazette, May 20, 1776 ; Barney, 40-43; Wallace's Life of Bradford, 367.</ref>
During the night, on 8 May, USS ''Roebuck'' finally cast off and the British dropped down the river. Captain Hallock (USS ''Wasp'') slipped back out of Christiana Creek, joining Captain Barry (USS ''Lexington''); both sailed out to join below [[w:Chester, Pennsylvania|Chester]] by thirteen Pennsylvania navy galleys. The galleys followed and another action took place, an engagement that lasted all the afternoon. An American prisoner, impressed on board the HMS ''Roebuck'', says that the galleys: :"‚Ä¶attacked the men-of-war the second day with more courage and conduct [and] the ''Roebuck'' received many shots betwixt wind and water; some went quite through, some in her quarter, and was much raked fore and aft‚Ä¶ During the engagement one man was killed by a shot which took his arm almost off. Six were much hurt and burned by an eighteen-pound cartridge of powder taking fire, among whom was an acting lieutenant."<ref>Am. Arch., IV, vi, 810.]</ref>
During the ensuing engagement, Capt. Hallock's seamen and the Continental marines captured the British brigantine HMS ''Betsey''. The British ships then retreated. In his official report to the admiral the captain of the HMS ''Roebuck'' says: :"On the 5th of May I took the ''Liverpool'' with me, sailed up the River as far as Wilmington, where I was attacked in a shallow part of the River by thirteen Row Gallies attended by several FireShips and Launches, which in two long Engagements I beat off and did my utmost to destroy‚Ä¶ After having fully executed what I had in view, I returned to the Capes the 15th."<ref>Brit. Adm. Rec., A. D. 487, November 28, 1776.</ref>
An evening later, lightning struck the USS ''Lexington'', forcing the ship to return home for repairs. Captain Barry and Captain William Hallock took their ship prizes into Philadelphia to be fitted for naval service in the Continental navy, arriving on 26 September 1776.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/l6/lexington-i.htm |title=USS ''Lexington'' |author=United States Navy Historical Center |date= |work=Dictionary of Naval Fighting Ships |publisher=Department of the Navy |accessdate=3 April 2010}} </ref> , the British officers were placed in jail. Captain John Barry cited his seamen and marines for fighting "with much courage."<ref>''Letter from Captain John Barry, CN, to Continental Marine Committee'' (7 April 1776), Naval Documents of the American Revolution, Volume IV: Paper 702. </ref> Two days later, Captain John Barry relinquished his command of the USS ''Lexington''.
====USS ''Lexington''‚Äî''Lady Susan''==== On 10 July 1776, the USS ''Lexington'', commandeered by sailed out to sea. On the 27 July, USS ''Lexington'' encountered the [[w:privateer|privateer]] ''Lady Susan'' from [[w:Lord Dunmore|Lord Dunmore's]] [[w:Tory|tory fleet]], which had been operating in and out of the [[w:Chesapeake Bay|Chesapeake Bay]]. ''Lady Susan'' was commanded by William Goodrich, a member of the notorious Tory family who had been harassing the merchant water routes of the colonies of [[w:Colony of Virginia|Virginia]] and [[w:Colony of Maryland|Maryland]]. Seven crew members from the captured privateer signed on for service with the Continental navy aboard USS ''Lexington''; one of the volunteers was [[w:Richard Dale|Richard Dale]] becoming Capt. Barry's [[w:midshipman|midshipman]], who later won fame under [[w:John Paul Jones|John Paul Jones]].
====Pennsylvania ''Nancy''‚ÄîHMS ''Kingfisher''==== The Continental marines aboard Captain [[w:Lambert Wickes|Lambert Wickes]]'s [[w:USS Reprisal|USS ''Reprisal'']] sailed the [[w:Delaware River|Delaware River]], and its approaches; and had been assisting other Continental vessels in service, for a few months seeing no sea battles until May 1776, when two British frigates were raiding [[w:Colony of Pennsylvania|colony of Pennsylvania's]] system of forts, barriers, and small warships created by the [[w:Pennsylvania Committee of Safety|Pennsylvania Committee of Safety]].<ref name=Jackson> {{cite book |title=The Pennsylvania Navy, 1775‚Äì1781 |last=Jackson |first=John W. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1974 |publisher=Rutgers University Press |location=[[w:New Brunswick, New Jersey|New Brunswick, New Jersey]] |isbn= |page= |pages=39‚Äì57 |url= |accessdate=}} </ref><ref name=Millet/>
On 10 June 1776, Captain Wickes, was ordered by the [[w:Marine Committee|Marine Committee]] to proceed to the French island possession of [[w:Martinique|Martinique]], in the [[w:Caribbean|Caribbean]]. The [[w:Committee of Secret Correspondence|Committee of Secret Correspondence]] of [[w:Second Continental Congress|Continental Congress]], issued orders for USS ''Reprisal'' to go acquire [[w:munitions|munitions]] and [[w:mat√©riel|mat√©riel]], and bring them for [[w:George Washington|General Washington]]'s [[w:Continental Army|Continental army]]. In addition, Captain Wickes was also assigned a diplomatic mission to transport [[w:William Bingham|William Bingham]], an ambassador for the [[w:Thirteen Colonies|United Colonies]], to his awaiting post. However, they did not cast sail immediately at once to the [[w:West Indies|West Indies]]; by end of the month Captain Wickes (USS ''Reprisal'') was still in [[w:Delaware Bay|Delaware Bay]].
Captains Lambert Wickes (USS ''Reprisal'') and [[w:John Barry|John Barry]] (USS ''Lexington'') both met at the lower approaches of the [[w:Delaware River|Delaware River]], on 20 June, as the both reached the [[w:Cape May|Cape May]]) in the [[w:Delaware Bay|Delaware Bay]].<ref> {{Cite encyclopedia |title=USS ''Lexington'' (1775) |encyclopedia=Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships |volume=Vol. 4, "L‚ÄìM" |page=100 |publisher=Naval History Division, Department of the Navy |location=Washington, DC; GPO |year=1969 |id= |accessdate=3 April 2010}} </ref> Momentarily, Captains Wickes and Barry enjoined [[w:USS Wasp (1775)|USS ''Wasp'']] and [[w:USS Hornet (1775)|USS ''Hornet'']] later the same day.
On 28 June, just as Captain Wickes (USS ''Reprisal'') turned to sail toward the [[w:Atlantic|Atlantic]] inbound on their Caribbean assignment, they spotting the [[w:Pennsylvania Navy|Pennsylvania navy's]] six-gun ''Nancy'' attempting to elude six British men-of-war blockaders and their tenders; still sailing, ''Nancy'' engaged the smaller tenders and managed to beat them off. The notorious British ship HMS ''Liverpool'' had been known to be enforcing the British blockade, preventing American ships from escaping to sea.<ref> {{Cite web |last=Bloom |first=Captain James |location=Charleston, New Hampshire |title=20 December 1776: The Indomitable Lexington |work=forum |publisher=Larkin |date=8 Jun 2005 |url=http://www.armchairgeneral.com/forums/showthread.php?t=28299 |accessdate=3 April 2010}} </ref> The Pennsylvanian brigantine was returning from [[w:St. Croix|St. Croix]] and [[w:Saint Thomas, United States Virgin Islands|St. Thomas]] of the [[w:United States Virgin Islands|Virgin Islands]], with 386 barrels of gunpowder, ammunition and military stores for the Continental army. The ''Reprisal'' and USS ''Lexington'' came to help aid ''Nancy's'', while under cover of a fog she was run ashore near Cape May, as its captain made an attempt to save the ship's precious cargo. As the fog soon lifted, they seen British sending in boats. Under fire, both, all four Continental vessels concentrated their cannons and musketry in preventing the British crew of [[w:HMS Kingfisher (1770)|HMS ''Kingfisher'']] from boarding ''Nancy''. During the engagement, the Continental marines and sailors mounted a gun on shore and opened fire on the men-of-war. Captain Wickes's third-lieutenant and brother [[w:Richard Wickes|Richard Wickes]], lost his life during the fight.<ref> {{Cite book |last=Fowler |first =William M., Jr. |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Rebels Under Sail: The American Navy during the Revolution. |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |year=1976 |location=New York City, NY |page=252 |url= |doi= |id= |isbn=}} </ref> The gunpowder was rowed ashore during the night, by morning the Americans left about 100 barrels of powder in the hold. Captain USS ''Nancy's'' captain and crew then set the brig on fire, with a large quantity of powder being still on board. The ship exploded as the British troops were boarding the brig ''Nancy'': :"and took possession of her with three cheers; soon after which the fire took the desired effect and blew the pirates forty or fifty yards into the air and much shattered one of their boats under her stern. Eleven dead bodies have since come on shore with two gold-laced hats and a leg with a garter. From the great number of limbs floating and driven ashore it is supposed thirty or forty of them were destroyed by the explosion."<ref>Am. Arch., V, i, 14.</ref>
However, the British have another account of the incident: :"‚Ä¶boarded amidst a heavy fire from the shore, where thousands of people had assembled to protect her. Finding it impossible to get her off, we set her on fire, with orders to quit her without loss of time, as we found her cargo consisted of three hundred and sixty barrels of powder with some saltpeter and dry goods; but unfortunately, before we had all left her, she blew up and a mate and six men was blown to pieces in her. The oars of the other boats were all knocked to atoms and two men had their ribs broke; but considering the whole, we was amazingly fortunate, as the pieces of the vessel was falling all round for some time."<ref>Navy Rec. Soc., vi, 35, Journal of Lieutenant James</ref>
====USS ''Reprisal''‚ÄîHMS ''Shark''====
Captain Wickes, and the Continental sailors and marines of USS ''Reprisal'' cleared [[w:Delaware Capes|Delaware Capes]] with thirteen merchantmen flanking at a safe distance; in the voyage they took and manned three prizes with sailors and marines, which left Captain Wickes'w fleet spread too thin while being very short-handed. After helping the captain and crew of the Pennsylvanian brigantine ''Nancy'' (who remained aboard USS ''Lexington''), Wickes proceeds to the south for the [[w:Caribbean|Caribbean]]. They sailed on July 3 for the [[w:West Indies|West Indies]], with their passenger, [[w:William Bingham|William Bingham]] the American commercial and naval agent, appointed to [[w:Martinique|Martinique]].
On July 27, as they approached off the coast of [[w:St. Pierre, Martinique|St. Pierre, Martinique]], Captain Wickes (USS ''Reprisal'') encountered the British 16-gun sloop-of-war [[w:HMS Shark (1776)|HMS ''Shark'']] and accompanying fleet of ships coming out of the harbor. A brutal cannonade erupted between the British and Americans. Captain Wickes prevailed in the battle and was able to acquire a few prizes in the event,<ref> {{Cite book |last=Miller |first=Nathan |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Sea of Glory: A Naval History of the American Revolution |publisher=United States Naval Institute (USNI) Press |year=197 |location=Annapolis, MD |page=118 |url= |doi= |id= |isbn=}} </ref> beating the British off and escaping into port. Captain Chapman of the HMS ''Shark'' says that at half-past five that afternoon a ship was seen coming around the northern point of the bay and was suspected of being an American. At seven the HMS ''Shark'' slipped her cables and made sail. Half an hour later the USS ''Reprisal'' attacked. :"We wore and stood towards him & haild him twice in French, to which he made no answer; we afterwards haild him in English, he continued to make sail from us & made no reply. At 9 fir'd a shot ahead of him and haild in English, told him we was an English Man of War; he made no answer, but bore down and fired a Broadside into us, which we returned immediately and continued engaging 1/2 an hour, then he back'd his Maintops & dropt astern & afterwards tack'd; 1/4 past 10 we tack'd & stood towards him, at 1/2 past 10 they fired two shot at us from the shore, which occasioned us to bear away; he kept his Wind and anchord in the Bay." <ref>Brit. Adm. Rec., Captain's Logs, No. 895 (log of the Shark.</ref>
Wickes says that be replied to both the French and English hail of the HMS ''Shark'' and that the latter fired a shot at ten o'clock followed by three others in succession, to which the USS ''Reprisal'' returned four, whereupon the English made sail in order to withdraw from the contest. A French officer on shore thought that the English fire was the more rapid and better delivered. He says that after parting from the USS ''Reprisal'', the HMS ''Shark'' chased a schooner, which took refuge under a battery; whereupon the battery fired two shots at the HMS ''Shark''. The next day they returned to their anchorage in the harbor.
The USS ''Reprisal'' returned to Philadelphia on 13 September 1776 and the sloop USS ''Independence'', commandeered by Captain John Young, was sent out to take command of USS ''Reprisal''.<ref>Am. Arch., V, i, 180, 249, 609, 706, 741, ii, 324, 410; Almon, iv, 103; Archives de la Marine, B7 458; Pap. Cont. Congr., 78, 23, 293, 295 (Wickes to Committee of Secret Correspondence, July 11, 13, 1776) ; Mar. Com. Letter Book, 20, 26 (September 20, October 4, 1776); Boston Gazette, August 19, October 7, 1776; Independent Chronicle, October 3, 1776.</ref>
====USS ''Lexington''‚ÄîHMS ''Pearl''==== With USS ''Lexington's'' repairs completed, Capt. William Hallock as its new commander sailed for [[w:Cap-Ha√Øtien|Cap-Fran√ßais]] (Cape Francois) to obtain a military cargo. On the return voyage, British frigate HMS ''Pearl'' overhauled the brigantine just short of the Delaware Capes, on 20 December, and captured her. The commander of the frigate removed USS ''Lexington‚Äôs'' officers but left 70 of her men on board under hatches with a prize crew. By luring their captors with a promise of rum, the Yankee sailors recaptured the ship and brought her to [[w:Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore, Maryland]].
===USS ''Andrew Doria''‚ÄîHMS ''Racehorse'', 1776=== Under order of the [[w:Secret Committee|Secret Committee]], Captain [[w:Isaiah Robinson|Isaiah Robinson]] sailed the Continental navy brigantine [[w:USS Andrew Doria (1775)|USS ''Andrew Doria'']] down the [[w:Delaware River|Delaware River]], on 17 October, for a [[w:Caribbean|Caribbean]] voyage to the [[w:Netherlands Antilles|Netherlands Antilles]] in the [[w:West Indies|West Indies]]. [[w:Second Continental Congress|Continental Congress]] issued authorization for the [[w:Marine Committee|Marine Committee]] to obtain a cargo of munitions and military supplies from the Dutch island [[w:Sint Eustatius|Sint Eustatius]]. Since the island sold [[w:weapon|weapons]] and [[w:ammunition|ammunition]] to anyone willing to pay, the island was one of the few ways to obtain [[w:mat√©riel|mat√©riels]] for [[w:George Washington|General Washington]]'s [[w:Continental Army|Continental army]]; also the commerce established good relations between Sint Eustatius and the [[w:Thirteen Colonies|United Colonies]].
Upon arrival on 16 November 1776, USS ''Andrew Doria'' fired its cannon a [[w:11-guns salute|11-guns salute]]; the Dutch governor [[w:Johannes de Graaff|Johannes de Graaff]] of Sint Eustatius decided to return the salute fire from Fort Oranje, rendering the foreign military ''first'' gun salute to an American [[w:Guidon (United_States)|guidon]] flying aboard an American naval ship, while anchored in a foreign port. Although the Dutch government later denied acknowledgment of the affair due to complaints by the British. However Governor Johannes de Graaff later recalled the statement. When the brig had loaded her cargo, she got underway for [[w:New England|New England]].
On 15 November 1776, while sailing past [[w:Puerto Rico|Puerto Rico]] on her homeward voyage, USS ''Andrew Doria'' encountered the [[w:Royal Navy|Royal Navy's]] 12-gun [[w:sloop-of-war|sloop-of-war]] [[w:Surprise (1777)|HMS ''Racehorse'']]. The sailors and marines fought for two-hour battle until they force the British to [[w:Striking the colors|strike their colors]] (or surrender). Robinson placed a crew of seamen and marines aboard the captured prize with orders to take her to back to [[w:Philadelphia|Philadelphia]], reaching it by January 1777.
===Princeton, 1777=== In late November 1776, [[w:George Washington|General Washington's]] Continental army positions along the [[w:Hudson River|Hudson River]] collapsed from the concurring assaults of British forces. In emergency response Washington requested assistance of a brigade of Philadelphia militia, a company of local seamen, and Major Nicholas's four companies of Continental marines. George Washington wrote a staunchly letter to [[w:John Cadwalader (general)|John Cadwalader]], a brigadier general of the [[w:Pennsylvania Associators|Pennsylvania Associators]]: :''"...if they came out resolved to act upon Land...instead their Services to the Water only."''‚ÄîGeorge Washington to John Cadwalader, 7 December 1776
On 2 December 1776, Major Samuel Nicholas and his three of his available companies‚Äîother two being Isaac Craig's and Robert Mullan's companies‚Äîof marines, garrisoned at the [[w:Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, Pennsylvania|Marine barracks]] in [[w:Philadelphia|Philadelphia]], were tasked to reinforce Washington's retreating army from [[w:New York|New York]] through [[w:Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]], to slow the progress of British troops that were moving southward through [[w:New Jersey|New Jersey]].<ref name=Hoffman/> The Major Nicholas and his companies of marines marched off to aid in support an American army for the first time in history; he led a battalion of 130 officers and enlisted men from Philadelphia, <ref name=Hoffman/> leaving behind one company to man the Continental vessels. Unsure what to do with the marines, Washington requested that the marines be attached to a brigade militiamen from the Philadelphia Associators, in which were also dressed in green uniforms alike of the Continental marines. Thus, Nicholas and his marines joined Calwalader's brigade of Pennsylvania Associators, a force of 1,200 men. The marines lived side-by-side with the militia brigade in [[w:Bristol, Pennsylvani|Bristol, Pennsylvania]] for two weeks waiting for an attack from the British. However, the British army instead went into winter quarters along the New Jersey shore of the [[w:Delaware River|Delaware River]].<ref name=Millet/>
General Washington attack the German garrison at Trenton on 25 December, though Calwalader's brigade (including the Continental marines under Samuel Nicholas) were unable to arrive in time to affect the [[w:battle of Trenton|battle for Trenton]], due to problems crossing the ice-choked Delaware River. Cadwalader finally crossed the river on 27 December on his own initiative, reaching Trenton by 2 January as Washington concentrated his army.<ref name=Millet/> As Cadwalader and his brigade managed to reach Trenton on 2 January from across the Delaware River, the Continental marines watched the cannonade between the Continental Army and [[w:Lord Cornwallis|Lord Cornwallis]]' British Army at [[w:Assunpink Creek|Assunpink Creek]]. The marines helped defend a crucial bridge against a [[w:Battle of Trenton#Hessian moves|Hessian attack]].<ref name=Hoffman/> <ref name="RevMarines"/>
On the night of 3 January, Calwalader's brigade (including Major Nicholas's battalion of Continental marines) and General Washington's Army silently departs the battlefield and marches toward [[w:Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]]. By daybreak, they launched a two-pronged attack.<ref name="RevMarines"/> The first prong of attack, led by Brigadier General [[w:Hugh Mercer|Hugh Mercer]], a close friend of George Washington, attacked a British stronghold. Mercer's brigade ran into heavy, well-disciplined musketry of two British regiments that were emplaced in front of Princeton, Mercer's brigade position soon collapsed.<ref name=Millet/> Calwalader's brigade (and marines) came to the assistance, but too stumbled into the British infantry forcing them to fall back. The second prong of attack caught the British in open flank, scattering three British regiments. It gave Washington's forces the advantage to take Princeton.<ref> {{cite book |last = Stryker |first = William S. |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = The Battles of Trenton and Princeton |publisher = Houghton Mifflin |year = 1898 |location = Boston, MA |url = |doi = |isbn =}} </ref> The battle for Princeton was the first engagement that the Continental marines fought and died in battle.
On 4 January, the remaining three marine companies encamped at its winter quartering at [[w:Sweets Town|Sweets Town]], not far from Washington's bivouac at [[w:Jockey Hollow|Jockey Hollow]], [[w:Morristown, New Jersey|Morristown]] in New Jersey. From 1 February 1777 and throughout the winter, the two companies of Nicholas's and Craig's marines either transferred to Morristown to assume the roles in the Continental artillery batteries, or left the service altogether.<ref name=Hoffman/> Robert Mullan and his company went back to Philadelphia, only to find that they no longer have a ship to serve aboard.<ref name=Millet/>
===St. Mary‚Äôs Isle‚ÄìWhitehaven, 1778=== On 23 April 1778, [[w:John Paul Jones|John Paul Jones]] and the Continental sailors and marines aboard [[w:USS Ranger (1777)|USS ''Ranger'']] made a raid on the British port of [[w:Whitehaven|Whitehaven, Great Britain]]. The seamen of USS ''Ranger'' set fire to ships and spiked the cannon of the fort. Later that same day, they land on [[w:St. Mary Isle|St. Mary Isle]] to capture a British earl, but find him away from home, and instead they take the family silver. The next day [24 April], USS ''Ranger'' and her marines defeat the British sloop HMS ''Drake'' in the [[w:Irish Sea|Irish Sea]].<ref name=Hoffman/>
===Lake Ponchartrain, 1778=== On 10 January, a company of Marines under Navy Captain [[w:James Willing|James Willing]] depart [[w:Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania)|Fort Pitt, Pennsylvania]] for an expedition, in the armed boat USS ''Rattletrap''. They sail into the [[w:Ohio River|Ohio River]] en route to [[w:New Orleans|New Orleans]].
Captain Willing and the Marines from USS ''Rattletrap'' captured the British sloop [[w:USS Morris (1778)|HMS ''Rebecca'']] while sailing down the [[w:Mississippi River|Mississippi River]]. They were able to temporarily weaken the British hold on the waterway from occupation. They raided British [[w:Loyalist|Loyalist]] plantations along on the shore of [[w:Lake Ponchartrain|Lake Ponchartrain]]. Marines from the frigate [[w:USS Randolph (1776)|USS ''Randolph'']] help extinguish a huge blaze on 15 January in [[w:Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston, South Carolina]], that destroyed hundred of buildings. They seized the forts, and captured five ships in the harbor.<ref name=Hoffman/>
A group under Navy Captain James Willing left [[w:Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh]], traveled down the [[w:Ohio River|Ohio]] and [[w:Mississippi River|Mississippi Rivers]], and captured a prize ship, which later becomes known as [[w:USS Morris (1778)|USS ''Morris'']] in the Continental Navy<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/m14/morris-i.htm |title=Morris |publisher=[[w:Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships|Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships]] |accessdate=7 February 2010}} </ref> Sailors and marines brought by ship from the [[w:Gulf of Mexico|Gulf of Mexico]], [[w:Battle of Lake Pontchartrain|raided British Loyalists]] on the shore of [[w:Lake Pontchartrain|Lake Pontchartrain]] on 10 September 1779.
===Penobscot, 1779=== Continental Marines landed and briefly captured [[w:Castine, Maine|Nautilus Island and the Majabagaduce peninsula]] in the [[w:Penobscot Expedition|Penobscot expedition]] in 1779, but withdrew with heavy losses when Commodore [[w:Dudley Saltonstall|Dudley Saltonstall]]'s force failed to capture the nearby fort.<ref> {{cite book |first=George E. |last=Buker |title=The Penobscot Expedition: Commodore Saltonstall and the Massachusetts Conspiracy of 1779 |location=Annapolis, Maryland |publisher=Naval Institute Press |year=2002 |ref=Buker |isbn=1-55750-212-9 |oclc=47869426}} </ref>
==References== ===Sources=== ===Notes=== {{reflist|2}} -----------------------------

page.title: User:RekonDog/Definitive History of the United States Marine Corps/Organizations

revision.text:
{{Template:USMC-History}} :See also: ''[[User:RekonDog/Sandbox/Definitive History of the United States Marine Corps/Appendix|Definitive History of the United States Marine Corps‚Äî Appendix]]'' ==First Marine Battalion: Samuel Nicolas== ===Table of Organization=== {| class="wikitable" border="2" |- ! colspan="8" align="center" | Commodore Esek Hopkins
Commander-in-Chief |- | align="center" width="150" | John B. Hopkins
USS ''Cabot'' | align="center" width="150" | Nicholas Biddle
USS ''Andrew Doria | align="center" width="150" | Dudley Saltonstall
USS ''Alfred'' | align="center" width="150" | Abraham Whipple
USS ''Columbus'' | align="center" width="150" | Abraham Whipple
USS ''Providence'' | align="center" width="150" | USS ''Wasp'' | align="center" width="150" | USS ''Hornet'' | align="center" width="150" | USS ''Fly'' |- | align="center" width="150" | | align="center" width="150" | Isaac Craig
Company Commander | align="center" width="150" | | align="center" width="150" | | align="center" width="150" | | align="center" width="150" | | align="center" width="150" | | align="center" width="150" | |} ====Isaac Craig's Company==== :Isaac Craig was born in Ireland about 1741, and moved to America in 1765 or 1767. He was a master carpenter and resided in the south part of the dock ward-city of Philadelphia. One source says he had a militia command prior to commission in continental Marines, but this is not proven. The continental Navy brigantine, the [[w:USS Andrew Doria (1775)|USS ''Andrew Doria'']], Lt. Isaac Craig and his men, served on board the USS ''Andrew Doria'' from December 1775 through September 21st, 1776. They sailed for New Providence in February and took part in the raid in March. He was commissioned a Captain on October 22nd, 1776 for service on the galley USS ''Champion''. They made only one cruise, returning in November of 1776. Craig and his men were sent as part of a small battalion of Marines under command of Samuel Nicholas with Captain Craig as his adjutant. In December, these Marines joined Colonel Cadwalder at Burlington, New Jersey. They participated in the Battle of Assunpink Creek (second battle of Trenton) and the Battle of Princeton, January 2nd and 3rd, 1777. In February of 1777 Craig‚Äôs company of Marines were assigned to the Artillery at Morristown. ===Table of Equipment=== The uniform regulations specified that standard uniform was a short green coat with white trim facings (lapels, cuffs, and coat lining) {{cite book |last=Smith |first=Charles Richard |coauthors=[[w:Charles Waterhouse (artist)|Charles H. Waterhouse]] |title=A Pictoral History: the Marines in the Revolution |publisher=United States Marine Corps Historical Division |year=1975 |url=http://www.marines.mil/news/publications/Documents/A%20Pictorial%20History-The%20Marines%20in%20the%20Revolution%20PCN%2019000317900.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-08-22}} , and a high leather collar to protect against cutlass slashes and to keep a man's head erect, leading to the nickname "[[w:leatherneck|leatherneck]]"; {{cite book |last=Simmons |first=Edwin Howard |title=The United States Marines: A History, 4th Edition |publisher=[[w:United States Naval Institute|Naval Institute Press]] |year=2003 |location=[[w:Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis, Maryland]] |isbn=1-59114-790-5}} complemented by a white waistcoat, white or buff short breeches, woolen stockings, and a short black gaiter. Marine officers wore small cocked hats, and a single [[w:epaulette|epaulette]]; {{cite book |last = Hoffman |first = Jon T. |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = USMC: A Complete History | publisher = Universe Publishing |year = 2002 |location = New York City, New York |url = |doi = |isbn = }} and the enlisted men sported round black hats with the brim pinned on one side. {{cite book | last=Millet | first=Allan R. | title=Semper Fidelis: The History of the United States Marine Corps |publisher=[[w:Free Press (publisher)|The Free Press]] | year=1991 | location=[[w:New York City|New York City, New York]] | isbn=1-59114-790-5}} The adoption of green coats and round hats probably reflects the constraints of availability, for both of the uniform attire were used by the Philadelphia Associators. {{cite book |last = McClellan |first = Edwin North |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Uniforms of the American Marines, 1775 to 1829 | publisher = Marine Corps History and Museums Division |year = 1974 [reprint] |location = Washington, D.C.; Maryland |url = |doi = |isbn = 1-59114-790-5}} It wasn't until the year 1777 that the Marines entirely appeared in uniform in numbers. Though legend attributes the green color to the traditional color of riflemen, Continental Marines mostly carried muskets. More likely, green cloth was simply plentiful in Philadelphia, and it served to distinguish Marines from the blue of the Army and Navy or the red of the British. {{Cite book |title=Report on Marine Corps Duplication of Effort between Army and Navy |author=United States Marine Corps |date=17 December 1932 |publisher=[[w:Marine Corps University|Marine Corps University]]}} Also, Sam Nicholas's hunting club wore green uniforms, hence his recommendation was for green. {{cite book |last=Col Chenoweth |first=H. Avery, USMCR (ret) |coauthors=Col Brooke Nihart, USMC (ret) |title=Semper fi: The Definitive Illustrated History of the U.S. Marines |publisher=[[w:Doubleday (publisher)|Main Street]] |year=2005 |location=New York |isbn=1-4027-3099-3}} Notably, Marines aboard [[w:USS Bonhomme Richard (1765)|USS ''Bonhomme Richard'']] wore red, though they were mostly [[w:Irish Brigade (French)|Irish soldiers of the French Army]]. ==References== {{reflist|2}}

page.title: VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Complex Numbers

revision.text:
<noinclude> {{Simple Page Navigation| BookName=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics]]| CurrentPage=Complex Numbers| PrevPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Circular Functions|Circular Functions]]|
NextPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Relations and Regions in the Complex Plane|Relations and Regions in the Complex Plane]]}}
</noinclude> == Preface ==
'''Formal Definition:''' A complex number is a number comprising a real and imaginary part (<math> z = x +yi </math>), where x and y are real numbers, and i is the standard imaginary unit with the property <math>i^2 = -1, i = \pm \sqrt{-1}</math>, a property that has led to the discovery of the fundamental theorem of algebra. The complex number field (<math>\mathbb{R} \in \mathbb{C}</math>) is a superset of the real number field.
'''Translation:''' i represents numbers that don't exist, and acts as a convenient placeholder, thus allowing one to get the roots of any polynomial. The fundamental theorem of algebra states that any polynomial as the same number of roots, as its highest power. All complex numbers are examples of vectors on a different plane, commonly called an Argand diagram. {{BookCat}}

page.title: VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Relations and Regions in the Complex Plane

revision.comment: created page + toc + preface + navbar + bookcat
revision.text:
<noinclude> {{Simple Page Navigation| BookName=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics]]| CurrentPage=Relations and Regions in the Complex Plane| PrevPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Complex Numbers|Complex Numbers]]|
NextPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Differential Calculus|Differential Calculus]]}}
</noinclude> == Preface ==
'''Formal Definition:''' In mathematics, the complex plane, z-plane, Argand diagrams are a geometric representation of the complex numbers established by the real axis and the orthogonal imaginary axis. It can be thought of as a modified Cartesian plane, with the real part of a complex number represented by a displacement along the x-axis, and the imaginary part by a displacement along the y-axis.
'''Translation:''' All complex numbers are vectors, they have direction, magnitude, and can be displayed using Cartesian-like coordinates on a modified Cartesian plane, or can be manipulated in polar form. Common formations are rays (angles), circles, ellipses, and other common Cartesian graphs. {{BookCat}}

page.title: VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Differential Calculus

revision.comment: created page + toc + preface + navbar + bookcat
revision.text:
<noinclude> {{Simple Page Navigation| BookName=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics]]| CurrentPage=Differential Calculus| PrevPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Relations and Regions in the Complex Plane|Relations and Regions in the Complex Plane]]|
NextPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Integral Calculus|Integral Calculus]]}}
</noinclude> == Preface ==
'''Formal Definition:''' In mathematics, differential calculus is a subfield of calculus concerned with the study of how functions change when their inputs change. The primary object of study in differential calculus is the derivative. A closely related notion is the differential. The derivative of a function at a chosen input value describes the behavior of the function near that input value. For a real-valued function of a single real variable, the derivative at a point equals the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function at that point. In general, the derivative of a function at a point determines the best linear approximation to the function at that point.
'''Translation:''' Its all about gradients, tangents, normals, finding turning points, and the nature of turning points - fast.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Integral Calculus

revision.comment: created page + toc + preface + navbar + bookcat
revision.text:
<noinclude> {{Simple Page Navigation| BookName=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics]]| CurrentPage=Integral Calculus| PrevPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Differential Calculus|Differential Calculus]]|
NextPage=[[VCE Specialist Mathematics/Units 3 and 4: Specialist Mathematics/Differential Equations|Differential Equations]]}}
</noinclude> == Preface ==
'''Formal Definition:''' Integration is an important concept in mathematics and, together with differentiation, is one of the two main operations in calculus. Given a function ∆í of a real variable x and an interval [a, b] of the real line, the definite integral is defined informally to be the net signed area of the region in the xy-plane bounded by the graph of ∆í, the x-axis, and the vertical lines x = a and x = b.
: <math>\int_a^b \! f(x)\,dx \,</math>
'''Translation:''' Its all about finding the equation of higher level graphs and the areas of lower level ones - fast.
{{BookCat}}

== Adding an application to the Audio category == '''In our case we will add din (music software) to the Applications Menu under xfce4:''' First, create a .desktop file via Create Launcher (right click), one can assing an icon and then when finished, it will appear on our Desktop. To have it showing up under the Audio menu entry then, simply copy it over to: /usr/share/applications after that run this on a terminal: sudo update-menus '''it will appear under the entry labeled: Other''' To make it appear under the '''Audio''' entry simply edit the .desktop file and add the following line: Categories=Audio;AudioVideo;Music; Re-run the update-menus command (as above). That's all, took me a while to figure it out since the xfce4 methods are a bit of a mess.. Thanks krgn for the help. {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Austncorp moved page [[Cookbook:Nilagang Baka]] to [[Cookbook:Boiled Beef and Vegetables in Broth (Nilagang Baka)]]: Conformed to recipe naming conventions.
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the Philippines|Cuisine of the Philippines]]
==Ingredients== * ¬Ω teaspoon black pepper (whole) * 1 onion (quarter-sliced) * 1 potato (quarter-sliced) * 1 cabbage (quarter-sliced) * 2 pieces of Chinese cabbage * 1 corn cob (quarter-sliced) * 2¬Ω kg. beef ribs * ¬Ω teaspoon salt * 2 onion chives * 2 pieces of ''saba''
==Procedure== # Boil beef till tender along with pepper, onion, salt, corn, & potato. # Slice onion chives to 3-in. strips. Put it alongside boiling beef. # Slice saba into half. Put it alongside boiling beef. # Serve in one large bowl or individual serving bowls. # Serve with rice on the side.
[[Category:Beef recipes]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes]] [[Category:Boiled recipes]] [[Category:Filipino recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]]

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Alejo!
[[Image:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' about the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[Wikibooks:Reading room/General|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Projects|interests you]]. If you're coming here from other Wikimedia projects, you should read [[Help:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|our primer for Wikimedians]] to get quickly up-to-speed.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* See the '''Wikibooks [[Help:Contents|help pages]]''' for common issues, or read [[Using Wikibooks]] for a more user-friendly introduction to the project. * Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Wikibooks:Reverting|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Files must be uploaded to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]], unless they are copyrighted and need to be uploaded here under [[w:fair use|fair use]]. If you need to upload a fair use file, you may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to do so. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:FILES|license tag]] and source are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}.
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[:w:Help:Edit summary|the edit summary]] and [[Help:Show preview|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[Help:Talk page|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only becomes available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
Thanks, --[[User:Belovedfreak|Belovedfreak]] ([[User talk:Belovedfreak|talk]]) 13:46, 2 April 2010 (UTC)
(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)

I was accused of spam, and my link phpforms.net/tutorial/tutorial.html - Introduction to CSS was removed and URL phpforms.net was banned. I apologize for my previous –∞ctions. I was badly informed about the rules and etiquette of Wikibooks. I have studied the rules in more details now. I want to ask to include phpforms.net/tutorial/tutorial.html#cat_180 - Introduction to CSS to this section. ‚ÄîPreceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Kalendos|Kalendos]] ([[User talk:Kalendos|discuss]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/Kalendos|contribs]]) I am sure that educational materials from phpforms.net/tutorial/tutorial.html#cat_180, that are written by programmers and web-developers, will be useful and interesting for readers. :I appreciate your words. You should now be able to add the link you've requested. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]] 16:11, 2 April 2010 (UTC)

== Opensource or not so opensource? ==
* http://cmap.ihmc.us/Support/faqs.php :Q. Could you send me the source code of CmapTools? :A. No, we do not distribute the source code of CmapTools. Only the executable programs are available. * http://cmap.ihmc.us/download/license_client.php * http://cmap.ihmc.us/download/license_server.php :You also agree not to reverse engineer, decompile, disassemble or otherwise attempt to discover the source code of the Software.
